executive_summary: Barbeque restaurants experienced some volatility in the last few years. Prior to the outbreak of COVID-19 and its subsequent economic impact, BBQ restaurants were bolstered by growth. When the pandemic hit, restaurant owners were forced to curtail dine-in operations, contributing to a massive dip in revenue in 2020. An uptick in take-away orders sustained many establishments during this time. Recovery was swift, however, once the government lifted stay-at-home orders, leaving consumers eager to eat out again. Rising consumer spending throughout the last few years has been a driver behind a rise in consumers dining out. Demand for BBQ has grown, with the impact of the pandemic on revenue growth being relatively brief. Revenue grew at a CAGR of 1.5% to $4.9 billion over the last five years, including a rise of 2.9% in 2024 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Once the pandemic was contained, travel restrictions faded and non-US residents resumed their travels. An up-tick in visitors to the US contributed to the wave of customers returning to dine-in at BBQ restaurants, as these visitors sought to experience traditional American cuisine.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: BBQ'S DIVERSE STYLES SATISFY VARIED TASTES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: BBQ restaurant owners tend to focus on the BBQ style most popular in their region. Southern BBQ has a long history in the US, featuring Carolina's pulled pork, Memphis's ribs and Alabama's smoked chicken. Texas BBQ is particularly famed, and highlights beef, especially brisket, slow-smoked over mesquite.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: POPULARITY OF BBQ SPURS COMPETITION FOR RESTAURATEURS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Demand for BBQ has been on the rise over the past decade, and menu items like pulled pork, brisket and ribs have been popular in many restaurants. As restaurants in other industries add industry products to their menus, external competition has been rising.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: HEALTHIER LIFESTYLES POSE A CHALLENGE AND OPPORTUNITY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Though healthy eating in the US has been on the decline, it is contracting at a slower rate as Americans increasingly become aware of the impact of what they eat. Barbecue menu items are not considered the healthiest fare. In response to rising health consciousness, restaurants have been slowly introducing menu items catering to the health-conscious consumer.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: BBQ Chefs will be inspired to create fusions between regional styles
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Barbeque will undergo an evolution that embraces a melting pot of flavors, converging various regional styles into unique culinary innovations. Chefs will explore global spice palettes, incorporating Latin American marinades or Asian-inspired rubs, creating fusion delicacies that redefine BBQ boundaries.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry include chain and franchised restaurants that mainly serve barbecue food. Restaurants may provide this food service in combination with selling alcoholic and other beverages. This industry does not include restaurants that sell a small portion of barbecue food as part of a wider cuisine.

key_trends: New BBQ restaurants require substantial investment and skilled workers to establish a competitive edge in the industry. An increase in demand for barbecue and relatively low barriers to entry have encouraged operators to enter the industry.

Customers of BBQ restaurants hold moderate power as there are various dining options available to them, influencing their pricing and quality expectations. Suppliers, especially for quality meat and BBQ equipment, can exert influence, but alternatives exist, balancing their power.

Alternative dining options like fast-food chains and home-cooked meals serve as substitutes for BBQ restaurants. DIY barbecue at home or ready-made BBQ meal kits present alternatives for those seeking BBQ flavors without dining out.
Over the five years to 2024, barbecue restaurants have an increase in demand, despite moderate setbacks during the pandemic.
Barbecue menu items like pulled pork, brisket and ribs have been trending in restaurants, both contributing to a growth in demand and increasing competition.

Health consciousness poses both challenges and opportunities for BBQ restaurants. Over the next few years, some restaurants will introduce new menu items that are healthier, while others will experiment with creating innovative fusions of BBQ styles.

Operators in the BBQ restaurant industry in the US can access various public resources, including small business loans and mentorship programs. Assistance is also available from industry-specific associations like the National Barbecue & Grilling Association (NBBQA).

BBQ restaurants in the US are subject to health and safety regulations set by local health departments, ensuring food handling, sanitation, and kitchen safety standards. There are also regulations concerning permits and licenses for food preparation and serving alcohol, varying by state and municipality.

Purchases are the highest cost for operating a BBQ restaurant. Menu engineering is a crucial aspect of controlling costs, and involves strategically pricing and promoting high-margin items to boost sales and profitability.

Wages are the second-largest expense incurred by industry operators, due to the expertise required for smoking and grilling meats. Amid the pandemic, temporary closures and capacity limitations forced many restaurants to furlough employees to reduce costs.

Households earning $70,000 to $150,000 account for the largest share of revenue for BBQ restaurants. This demographic is moderately affluent, and have greater disposable income. Economic stability allows for indulgence in dining out, contributing to increased patronage at BBQ restaurants for this group.

On-site dining is the most popular option for consumers who want to eat BBQ, though this option was severely limited during the pandemic. With restrictions eased, there has been a resurgence in the demand for on-site dining, as people have been eager to dine out.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Households earning less than $30,000 annually make up a demographic facing financial constraints, and usually prioritize essential spending over dining out. Lower-income brackets might seek more affordable dining options or opt for home cooking, potentially decreasing foot traffic to BBQ restaurants.

Households earning between $30,000 to $70,000 annually represent a middle-income bracket that can budget for discretionary spending on non-essential purchases, like dining out. Economic fluctuations can impact this group's spending habits; however, they often allocate a portion of their budget for restaurant experiences, including visits to BBQ establishments.

Households earning between $70,000 to $150,000 annually represent a moderately affluent demographic, often with more disposable income for discretionary spending. Economic stability allows for indulgence in dining out, contributing to increased patronage at BBQ restaurants for leisurely meals and social gatherings.

Households earning $150,000 or more annually have access to considerable disposable income, allowing for splurging on dining experiences and other luxuries. This segment seeks high-quality dining experiences, leading to visits to BBQ restaurants offering premium cuts, gourmet sides or exclusive dining settings.

products_and_services.product_description: On-site dining is the most popular option for consumers who want to eat BBQ, though this option was severely limited during the pandemic. With restrictions eased, there has been a resurgence in the demand for on-site dining, as people have been eager to dine out.

Take-out and delivery services allow customers to order food from restaurants for pick-up or home delivery, offering quality meals with convenience and flexibility. Changing lifestyles, busy schedules and home dining during the pandemic has bolstered demand for take-out and delivery options across various cuisines, including BBQ.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita disposable income represents the money consumers have to allocate toward discretionary purchases. Trends in per capita disposable income levels influence demand for dining out, as for most individuals this is a non-essential expenditure. When per capita disposable income falls, it poses a potential threat to the industry.

The Southwest region follows with 15% of establishments and 12% of the population.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Profit margins have decreased from 5.5% of industry revenue in 2019 to 5.0% in 2024. Profitability is highly dependent on a restaurant owner's ability to manage expenses. Menu engineering is a crucial aspect of controlling costs, and involves strategically pricing and promoting high-margin items to boost sales and profitability.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skilled and Kitchen Staff Require Fair Wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Like other food service establishments, barbeque restaurants rely on highly skilled staff and trained pitmasters, waiters as well as managers and other general support staff. Wages are the second-largest expense incurred by industry operators, due to the expertise required for smoking and grilling meats.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Vary Depending on the Size and Location of a Restaurant
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Food and beverages are usually purchased from wholesalers, and volatile input costs can cause the prices to fluctuate. Restaurants with more buying Power, like those that are part of a chain, tend to be able to buy in bulk and lower their costs.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The Pandemic Created Supply Chain Disruptions
volatility_points.volatility_description: The outbreak of COVID-19 created supply chain disruptions that affected availability of key ingredients like quality meat. Shortages in essential ingredients impact menu availability and pricing, lead to inconsistent menu offerings.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Fast-Casual Restaurant Model Becomes Increasingly Popular
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The expansion of fast-casual dining has revolutionized the BBQ scene, offering a contemporary twist on traditional slow-cooked flavors. This format combines speed with customization, allowing customers to craft their BBQ plates quickly and easily, without compromising on quality.

FAQs.question: What were the impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic on supply chains?
FAQs.answer: The outbreak of COVID-19 created supply chain disruptions that affected availability of key ingredients like quality meat. Shortages in essential ingredients impact menu availability and pricing, lead to inconsistent menu offerings.

FAQs.question: How did supply chain disruptions affect profits and pricing?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuating costs due to supply chain disruptions affect profit margins, forcing adjustments in pricing. Though it is important to mitigate profit loss, raising prices always runs the risk of alienating some customers.
